article.Heading: Budget 2016: FM announces all-time high agricultural credit of Rs 9 lk crore
article.Summary: During the last Budget, the government had outlined target of Rs 8.5 lakh crore of agricultural credit.
article.Body:
Shweta Mungre
moneycontrol.com

While presenting the Budget for 2016-17 on Monday, the Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced an all-time high agricultural credit of Rs 9.0 lakh crore.

He also announced a provision of Rs 15000 crore towards interest subvention to reduce burden of loan repayment. 

During the last Budget, the government had outlined target of Rs 8.5 lakh crore of agricultural credit.

In a pre-Budget note, Standard Chartered had outlined the need for model legislation for digital registration of tenancy agreements between landowners and farmers. This would help in formally classifying farmers and landowners as cultivators and improve their access to institutional credit.

Various initiatives have also been put in place to aid farmers, like crop loans up to Rs 3 lakh at 7 percent interest, the effective rate of which was cut to 4 percent during 2015-16 as an incentive for prompt repayment. These measures were aimed at helping farmers tide over short-term contingencies and price shocks which may affect their seasonal operations.

The small and marginal farmers with Kisan Credit Cards (KCCs) also have the benefit of interest subvention scheme extended for a further period of up to six months (post-harvest) against Negotiable Warehouse Receipts (NWRs), at the same rate as available to crop loan, to discourage distress sale of crops by small farmers.

However, it is interesting to note that although the ratio of agricultural credit to agricultural GDP has nearly quadrupled in percentage terms within a decade up to 2013, the share of long-term agriculture credit has declined significantly dropped.

The Macro-Economic Survey tabled in the Parliament on Friday had pointed out the immediate need to arrest and reverse this decline.
